comment_text.mn109:1.1: This discourse is also found at SN 22.82, with only minor differences in readings.
comment_text.mn109:3.2: The commentary says that he asked these questions in order to educate his students. This seems probable in view of the fact that the sequence of questions is structured in a way that is clearly purposeful.
comment_text.mn109:4.5: The remainder of the discourse omits these responses, but they are mostly included in the parallel (see note on SN 22.82:4.2).
comment_text.mn109:5.2: “Desire” (chanda) is the fundamental driving force underlying all manifestations of the aggregates. It is the same as “craving” (taṇhā).
comment_text.mn109:7.4: This assumes the persistence of a “self” through time.
comment_text.mn109:8.1: The question is whether there is anything outside the aggregates.
comment_text.mn109:8.7: That is to say, the term “aggregate” (khandha) is a collective term for all instances of this kind of phenomenon.
comment_text.mn109:9.1: While the “root” of all aggregates is desire, the question now is the immediate basis of each particular aggregate.
comment_text.mn109:9.7: In dependent origination, “contact” (phassa) is the immediate condition for “feeling” (vedanā). But contact can also be regarded as the immediate condition for all three: feeling, perception, and choices (eg. SN 35.93:1.14). These things are always active in consciousness, so they can be treated as simultaneous, as arising in sequence, or as mutually conditioning.
comment_text.mn109:9.8: Feeling and “perception” (saññā) are closely connected, since how we feel conditions how we recognize and interpret. While contact directly underlies feeling, perception works so quickly that is can be included as a direct consequence as well.
comment_text.mn109:9.9: Likewise with “choices” (saṅkhārā), which are also part of the complex of reactivity that normally take effect immediately. For example, suppose we try eating a berry in the forest. “Contact” with its bitter taste “feels” unpleasant, so we “perceive” it as poisonous, and “choose” to spit it out.
comment_text.mn109:9.10: Normally in dependent origination, it is consciousness that is a condition for name and form. The presentation here assumes their mutual conditioning, as spelled out at DN 15:22.1. Name and form are the embryo that supports consciousness in the process of rebirth, while the physical body with its senses, and the psychological functions included under “name” continue to evolve and grow with consciousness through life.
comment_text.mn109:10.8: That is to say, the “substantialist” view takes the aggregates, or one of them, to be a “substantial reality” that is identified with the self. Such views are created each time we think or attach to the aggregates as a self.
comment_text.mn109:11.8: Since substantialist view is itself a conditioned phenomenon, it can only continue to exist if it is continually reinforced. Without it, like a fire without a constant supply of fuel, it falters and goes out.
comment_text.mn109:12.1: We have met these questions before at MN 13:6.2. Here they build on the previous section by showing a strategy for how to stop identifying them as the substantial reality underlying the self. This can be used as the basis for a contemplative insight meditation.
comment_text.mn109:13.1: From meditative contemplation, the question now turns to realization. The Buddha’s response makes it clear he is now speaking of the penetrative understanding of the aggregates that arises at stream-entry at least. The “underlying tendency to conceit”, however, is only fully overcome by the arahant. | “I-making” (ahaṅkāra) emphasizes the active role of the mind in creating a sense of self through its thoughts, habits, and desires. This is in contrast with the English notion of “ego”, which presents self as a given construct. | “Mine-making” (mamaṅkāra) is the propensity of the mind to appropriate things as possessions. | “All signs” (sabbanimitta) are the “features” (also nimitta) that characterize sensory stimulation (eg. MN 112:15.1).
comment_text.mn109:14.2: In his mind, the monk addresses the Buddha with “worthy sir” (bho), which is a signature of the brahmins (MN 98:11.3). Small wonder he still assumes a self.
comment_text.mn109:14.3: This monk, missing the point, thinks not-self means he can escape moral responsibility. A theory of self assumes a continuous entity, so that deeds done at one time will affect the same entity at another time. The Buddhist concept, on the other hand, is of a flow, so that, for example, pollution dumped in a stream will affect the river and the sea below, even though they are not materially the “same”.
comment_text.mn109:14.8: Read paṭipucchāvinītā with SN 22.82:13.4. It is the name for the method of questioning the Buddha is about to use. The Buddha does not just state doctrine for his students, he has “educated” (vinīta) them in the methods for learning. Active questioning breaks up long discourses and encourages reflection and articulation.
comment_text.mn109:18.4: The parallel at SN 22.82:15.1 has a completely different closing passage. Generally speaking, such passages were added at a later date to wrap up the teaching portion, and there is considerable variation within the Pali texts, let alone Chinese and other parallels.

root_text.mn109:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā sāvatthiyaṁ viharati pubbārāme migāramātupāsāde.
root_text.mn109:2.1: Tena kho pana samayena bhagavā tadahuposathe pannarase puṇṇāya puṇṇamāya rattiyā bhikkhusaṅghaparivuto abbhokāse nisinno hoti.
root_text.mn109:3.1: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu uṭṭhāyāsanā ekaṁsaṁ cīvaraṁ katvā yena bhagavā tenañjaliṁ paṇāmetvā bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn109:3.2: “Puccheyyāhaṁ, bhante, bhagavantaṁ kiñcideva desaṁ, sace me bhagavā okāsaṁ karoti pañhassa veyyākaraṇāyā”ti.
root_text.mn109:3.3: “Tena hi tvaṁ, bhikkhu, sake āsane nisīditvā puccha yadākaṅkhasī”ti.
root_text.mn109:3.4: Atha kho so bhikkhu sake āsane nisīditvā bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn109:4.5: “Sādhu, bhante”ti kho so bhikkhu bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinanditvā anumoditvā bhagavantaṁ uttariṁ pañhaṁ pucchi:
root_text.mn109:6.1: “Taṁyeva nu kho, bhante, upādānaṁ te pañcupādānakkhandhā, udāhu aññatra pañcahupādānakkhandhehi upādānan”ti?
root_text.mn109:6.2: “Na kho, bhikkhu, taṁyeva upādānaṁ te pañcupādānakkhandhā, nāpi aññatra pañcahupādānakkhandhehi upādānaṁ.
root_text.mn109:6.3: Yo kho, bhikkhu, pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu chandarāgo taṁ tattha upādānan”ti.
root_text.mn109:7.4: ‘evaṁrūpo siyaṁ anāgatamaddhānaṁ, evaṁvedano siyaṁ anāgatamaddhānaṁ, evaṁsañño siyaṁ anāgatamaddhānaṁ, evaṁsaṅkhāro siyaṁ anāgatamaddhānaṁ, evaṁviññāṇo siyaṁ anāgatamaddhānan’ti.
root_text.mn109:7.5: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhu, siyā pañcasu upādānakkhandhesu chandarāgavemattatā”ti.
root_text.mn109:8.2: “Yaṁ kiñci, bhikkhu, rūpaṁ—atītānāgatapaccuppannaṁ ajjhattaṁ vā bahiddhā vā, oḷārikaṁ vā sukhumaṁ vā, hīnaṁ vā paṇītaṁ vā, yaṁ dūre santike vā—ayaṁ rūpakkhandho.
root_text.mn109:8.3: Yā kāci vedanā—atītānāgatapaccuppannā ajjhattaṁ vā bahiddhā vā, oḷārikā vā sukhumā vā, hīnā vā paṇītā vā, yā dūre santike vā—ayaṁ vedanākkhandho.
root_text.mn109:8.4: Yā kāci saññā—atītānāgatapaccuppannā …pe… yā dūre santike vā—ayaṁ saññākkhandho.
root_text.mn109:8.5: Ye keci saṅkhārā—atītānāgatapaccuppannā ajjhattaṁ vā bahiddhā vā, oḷārikā vā sukhumā vā, hīnā vā paṇītā vā, ye dūre santike vā—ayaṁ saṅkhārakkhandho.
root_text.mn109:8.6: Yaṁ kiñci viññāṇaṁ—atītānāgatapaccuppannaṁ ajjhattaṁ vā bahiddhā vā, oḷārikaṁ vā sukhumaṁ vā, hīnaṁ vā paṇītaṁ vā, yaṁ dūre santike vā—ayaṁ viññāṇakkhandho.
root_text.mn109:8.7: Ettāvatā kho, bhikkhu, khandhānaṁ khandhādhivacanaṁ hotī”ti.
root_text.mn109:9.1: “Ko nu kho, bhante, hetu ko paccayo rūpakkhandhassa paññāpanāya?
root_text.mn109:9.2: Ko hetu ko paccayo vedanākkhandhassa paññāpanāya?
root_text.mn109:9.3: Ko hetu ko paccayo saññākkhandhassa paññāpanāya?
root_text.mn109:9.4: Ko hetu ko paccayo saṅkhārakkhandhassa paññāpanāya?
root_text.mn109:9.5: Ko hetu ko paccayo viññāṇakkhandhassa paññāpanāyā”ti?
root_text.mn109:9.6: “Cattāro kho, bhikkhu, mahābhūtā hetu, cattāro mahābhūtā paccayo rūpakkhandhassa paññāpanāya.
root_text.mn109:9.7: Phasso hetu, phasso paccayo vedanākkhandhassa paññāpanāya.
root_text.mn109:9.8: Phasso hetu, phasso paccayo saññākkhandhassa paññāpanāya.
root_text.mn109:9.9: Phasso hetu, phasso paccayo saṅkhārakkhandhassa paññāpanāya.
root_text.mn109:9.10: Nāmarūpaṁ kho, bhikkhu, hetu, nāmarūpaṁ paccayo viññāṇakkhandhassa paññāpanāyā”ti.
root_text.mn109:10.2: “Idha, bhikkhu, assutavā puthujjano ariyānaṁ adassāvī ariyadhammassa akovido ariyadhamme avinīto sappurisānaṁ adassāvī sappurisadhammassa akovido sappurisadhamme avinīto
root_text.mn109:10.3: rūpaṁ attato samanupassati rūpavantaṁ vā attānaṁ attani vā rūpaṁ rūpasmiṁ vā attānaṁ;
root_text.mn109:10.4: vedanaṁ attato samanupassati vedanāvantaṁ vā attānaṁ attani vā vedanaṁ vedanāya vā attānaṁ;
root_text.mn109:10.5: saññaṁ attato samanupassati saññāvantaṁ vā attānaṁ attani vā saññaṁ saññāya vā attānaṁ;
root_text.mn109:10.6: saṅkhāre attato samanupassati saṅkhāravantaṁ vā attānaṁ attani vā saṅkhāre saṅkhāresu vā attānaṁ;
root_text.mn109:10.7: viññāṇaṁ attato samanupassati viññāṇavantaṁ vā attānaṁ attani vā viññāṇaṁ viññāṇasmiṁ vā attānaṁ.
root_text.mn109:11.2: “Idha, bhikkhu, sutavā ariyasāvako ariyānaṁ dassāvī ariyadhammassa kovido ariyadhamme suvinīto sappurisānaṁ dassāvī sappurisadhammassa kovido sappurisadhamme suvinīto
root_text.mn109:11.3: na rūpaṁ attato samanupassati na rūpavantaṁ vā attānaṁ na attani vā rūpaṁ na rūpasmiṁ vā attānaṁ;
root_text.mn109:11.4: na vedanaṁ attato samanupassati na vedanāvantaṁ vā attānaṁ na attani vā vedanaṁ na vedanāya vā attānaṁ;
root_text.mn109:11.5: na saññaṁ attato samanupassati na saññāvantaṁ vā attānaṁ na attani vā saññaṁ na saññāya vā attānaṁ;
root_text.mn109:11.6: na saṅkhāre attato samanupassati na saṅkhāravantaṁ vā attānaṁ na attani vā saṅkhāre na saṅkhāresu vā attānaṁ;
root_text.mn109:11.7: na viññāṇaṁ attato samanupassati na viññāṇavantaṁ vā attānaṁ na attani vā viññāṇaṁ na viññāṇasmiṁ vā attānaṁ.
root_text.mn109:11.8: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhu, sakkāyadiṭṭhi na hotī”ti.
root_text.mn109:12.1: “Ko nu kho, bhante, rūpe assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṁ nissaraṇaṁ?
root_text.mn109:12.2: Ko vedanāya assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṁ nissaraṇaṁ?
root_text.mn109:12.3: Ko saññāya assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṁ nissaraṇaṁ?
root_text.mn109:12.4: Ko saṅkhāresu assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṁ nissaraṇaṁ?
root_text.mn109:12.5: Ko viññāṇe assādo, ko ādīnavo, kiṁ nissaraṇan”ti?
root_text.mn109:12.6: “Yaṁ kho, bhikkhu, rūpaṁ paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṁ somanassaṁ, ayaṁ rūpe assādo.
root_text.mn109:12.7: Yaṁ rūpaṁ aniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vipariṇāmadhammaṁ, ayaṁ rūpe ādīnavo.
root_text.mn109:12.8: Yo rūpe chandarāgavinayo chandarāgappahānaṁ, idaṁ rūpe nissaraṇaṁ.
root_text.mn109:12.12: viññāṇaṁ paṭicca uppajjati sukhaṁ somanassaṁ, ayaṁ viññāṇe assādo.
root_text.mn109:12.13: Yaṁ viññāṇaṁ aniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vipariṇāmadhammaṁ, ayaṁ viññāṇe ādīnavo.
root_text.mn109:12.14: Yo viññāṇe chandarāgavinayo chandarāgappahānaṁ, idaṁ viññāṇe nissaraṇan”ti.
root_text.mn109:13.1: “Kathaṁ pana, bhante, jānato kathaṁ passato imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā na hontī”ti?
root_text.mn109:13.2: “Yaṁ kiñci, bhikkhu, rūpaṁ—atītānāgatapaccuppannaṁ ajjhattaṁ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṁ vā sukhumaṁ vā hīnaṁ vā paṇītaṁ vā yaṁ dūre santike vā—sabbaṁ rūpaṁ ‘netaṁ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti—evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya passati.
root_text.mn109:13.6: yaṁ kiñci viññāṇaṁ—atītānāgatapaccuppannaṁ ajjhattaṁ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṁ vā sukhumaṁ vā hīnaṁ vā paṇītaṁ vā yaṁ dūre santike vā—sabbaṁ viññāṇaṁ ‘netaṁ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti—evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya passati.
root_text.mn109:13.7: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhu, jānato evaṁ passato imasmiñca saviññāṇake kāye bahiddhā ca sabbanimittesu ahaṅkāramamaṅkāramānānusayā na hontī”ti.
root_text.mn109:14.1: Atha kho aññatarassa bhikkhuno evaṁ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
root_text.mn109:14.2: “iti kira, bho, rūpaṁ anattā, vedanā anattā, saññā anattā, saṅkhārā anattā, viññāṇaṁ anattā;
root_text.mn109:14.4: Atha kho bhagavā tassa bhikkhuno cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya bhikkhū āmantesi:
root_text.mn109:14.5: “ṭhānaṁ kho panetaṁ, bhikkhave, vijjati yaṁ idhekacco moghapuriso avidvā avijjāgato taṇhādhipateyyena cetasā satthu sāsanaṁ atidhāvitabbaṁ maññeyya:
root_text.mn109:14.6: ‘iti kira, bho, rūpaṁ anattā, vedanā anattā, saññā anattā, saṅkhārā anattā, viññāṇaṁ anattā;
root_text.mn109:14.8: Paṭivinītā kho me tumhe, bhikkhave, tatra tatra dhammesu.
root_text.mn109:15.4: “Yaṁ panāniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vā taṁ sukhaṁ vā”ti?
root_text.mn109:15.6: “Yaṁ panāniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vipariṇāmadhammaṁ, kallaṁ nu taṁ samanupassituṁ:
root_text.mn109:16.7: “Yaṁ panāniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vā taṁ sukhaṁ vā”ti?
root_text.mn109:16.9: “Yaṁ panāniccaṁ dukkhaṁ vipariṇāmadhammaṁ, kallaṁ nu taṁ samanupassituṁ:
root_text.mn109:16.12: “Tasmātiha, bhikkhave, yaṁ kiñci rūpaṁ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṁ ajjhattaṁ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṁ vā sukhumaṁ vā hīnaṁ vā paṇītaṁ vā yaṁ dūre santike vā sabbaṁ rūpaṁ: ‘netaṁ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṁ.
root_text.mn109:17.4: yaṁ kiñci viññāṇaṁ atītānāgatapaccuppannaṁ ajjhattaṁ vā bahiddhā vā oḷārikaṁ vā sukhumaṁ vā hīnaṁ vā paṇītaṁ vā yaṁ dūre santike vā sabbaṁ viññāṇaṁ: ‘netaṁ mama, nesohamasmi, na meso attā’ti evametaṁ yathābhūtaṁ sammappaññāya daṭṭhabbaṁ.
root_text.mn109:17.5: Evaṁ passaṁ, bhikkhave, sutavā ariyasāvako rūpasmimpi nibbindati, vedanāyapi nibbindati, saññāyapi nibbindati, saṅkhāresupi nibbindati, viññāṇasmimpi nibbindati;
root_text.mn109:18.1: nibbindaṁ virajjati, virāgā vimuccati. Vimuttasmiṁ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṁ hoti.
root_text.mn109:18.2: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānātī”ti.
root_text.mn109:18.4: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.
root_text.mn109:18.5: Imasmiñca pana veyyākaraṇasmiṁ bhaññamāne saṭṭhimattānaṁ bhikkhūnaṁ anupādāya āsavehi cittāni vimucciṁsūti.

translation_text.mn109:0.2: The Longer Discourse on the Full-Moon Night
translation_text.mn109:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Sāvatthī in the stilt longhouse of Migāra’s mother in the Eastern Monastery.
translation_text.mn109:2.1: Now, at that time it was the sabbath—the full moon on the fifteenth day—and the Buddha was sitting in the open surrounded by the Saṅgha of monks.
translation_text.mn109:3.1: Then one of the mendicants got up from their seat, arranged their robe over one shoulder, raised their joined palms toward the Buddha, and said,
translation_text.mn109:3.2: “Sir, I’d like to ask the Buddha about a certain point, if you’d take the time to answer.”
translation_text.mn109:3.3: “Well then, mendicant, take your own seat and ask what you wish.”
translation_text.mn109:3.4: That mendicant took his seat and said to the Buddha:
translation_text.mn109:4.1: “Sir, are these the five grasping aggregates:
translation_text.mn109:4.2: form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness?”
translation_text.mn109:4.5: Saying “Good, sir”, that mendicant approved and agreed with what the Buddha said. Then he asked another question:
translation_text.mn109:5.1: “But sir, what is the root of these five grasping aggregates?”
translation_text.mn109:5.2: “These five grasping aggregates are rooted in desire.”
translation_text.mn109:6.1: “But sir, is that grasping the exact same thing as the five grasping aggregates? Or is grasping one thing and the five grasping aggregates another?”
translation_text.mn109:6.3: The desire and greed for the five grasping aggregates is the grasping there.”
translation_text.mn109:7.1: “But sir, can there be disparity in desire and greed for the five grasping aggregates?”
translation_text.mn109:7.4: ‘In the future, may I be of such form, such feeling, such perception, such choices, and such consciousness!’
translation_text.mn109:7.5: That’s how there can be disparity in desire and greed for the five grasping aggregates.”
translation_text.mn109:8.1: “Sir, what is the scope of the term ‘aggregates’ as applied to the aggregates?”
translation_text.mn109:8.2: “Any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: this is called the aggregate of form.
translation_text.mn109:8.3: Any kind of feeling at all …
translation_text.mn109:8.4: Any kind of perception at all …
translation_text.mn109:8.5: Any kind of choices at all …
translation_text.mn109:8.6: Any kind of consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: this is called the aggregate of consciousness.
translation_text.mn109:8.7: That’s the scope of the term ‘aggregates’ as applied to the aggregates.”
translation_text.mn109:9.1: “What is the cause, sir, what is the reason why the aggregate of form is found?
translation_text.mn109:9.2: What is the cause, what is the reason why the aggregate of feeling …
translation_text.mn109:9.6: “The four principal states are the reason why the aggregate of form is found.
translation_text.mn109:9.7: Contact is the reason why the aggregates of feeling,
translation_text.mn109:9.10: Name and form are the reasons why the aggregate of consciousness is found.”
translation_text.mn109:10.1: “But sir, how does substantialist view come about?”
translation_text.mn109:10.2: “It’s when an unlearned ordinary person has not seen the noble ones, and is neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve not seen true persons, and are neither skilled nor trained in the teaching of the true persons.
translation_text.mn109:10.3: They regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.
translation_text.mn109:10.4: They regard feeling as self, self as having feeling, feeling in self, or self in feeling.
translation_text.mn109:10.5: They regard perception as self, self as having perception, perception in self, or self in perception.
translation_text.mn109:10.6: They regard choices as self, self as having choices, choices in self, or self in choices.
translation_text.mn109:10.7: They regard consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.
translation_text.mn109:10.8: That’s how substantialist view comes about.”
translation_text.mn109:11.1: “But sir, how does substantialist view not come about?”
translation_text.mn109:11.2: “It’s when a learned noble disciple has seen the noble ones, and is skilled and trained in the teaching of the noble ones. They’ve seen true persons, and are skilled and trained in the teaching of the true persons.
translation_text.mn109:11.3: They don’t regard form as self, self as having form, form in self, or self in form.
translation_text.mn109:11.4: They don’t regard feeling as self, self as having feeling, feeling in self, or self in feeling.
translation_text.mn109:11.5: They don’t regard perception as self, self as having perception, perception in self, or self in perception.
translation_text.mn109:11.6: They don’t regard choices as self, self as having choices, choices in self, or self in choices.
translation_text.mn109:11.7: They don’t regard consciousness as self, self as having consciousness, consciousness in self, or self in consciousness.
translation_text.mn109:11.8: That’s how substantialist view does not come about.”
translation_text.mn109:12.1: “Sir, what’s the gratification, the drawback, and the escape when it comes to form,
translation_text.mn109:12.6: “The pleasure and happiness that arise from form: this is its gratification.
translation_text.mn109:12.7: That form is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.
translation_text.mn109:12.8: Removing and giving up desire and greed for form: this is its escape.
translation_text.mn109:12.9: The pleasure and happiness that arise from feeling …
translation_text.mn109:12.13: That consciousness is impermanent, suffering, and perishable: this is its drawback.
translation_text.mn109:12.14: Removing and giving up desire and greed for consciousness: this is its escape.”
translation_text.mn109:13.1: “Sir, how does one know and see so that there’s no I-making, mine-making, or underlying tendency to conceit for this conscious body and externally for all signs?”
translation_text.mn109:13.2: “One truly sees any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
translation_text.mn109:13.3: One truly sees any kind of feeling …
translation_text.mn109:13.6: consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near, all consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
translation_text.mn109:13.7: That’s how to know and see so that there’s no I-making, mine-making, or underlying tendency to conceit for this conscious body and externally for all signs.”
translation_text.mn109:14.1: Now at that time one of the mendicants had the thought,
translation_text.mn109:14.2: “So it seems, worthy sir, that form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness are not-self.
translation_text.mn109:14.3: Then how will the deeds done by not-self affect the self?”
translation_text.mn109:14.4: But the Buddha, knowing that mendicant’s train of thought, addressed the mendicants:
translation_text.mn109:14.5: “It’s possible that some futile person here—unknowing and ignorant, their mind dominated by craving—thinks they can overstep the teacher’s instructions. They think:
translation_text.mn109:14.6: ‘So it seems, worthy sir, that form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness are not-self.
translation_text.mn109:14.7: Then how will the deeds done by not-self affect the self?’
translation_text.mn109:14.8: Now, mendicants, you have been educated by me in questioning with regard to all these things in all such cases.
translation_text.mn109:15.4: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
translation_text.mn109:15.6: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:
translation_text.mn109:15.7: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
translation_text.mn109:16.7: “But if it’s impermanent, is it suffering or happiness?”
translation_text.mn109:16.9: “But if it’s impermanent, suffering, and perishable, is it fit to be regarded thus:
translation_text.mn109:16.10: ‘This is mine, I am this, this is my self’?”
translation_text.mn109:16.12: “So you should truly see any kind of form at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near: all form—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
translation_text.mn109:17.1: You should truly see any kind of feeling …
translation_text.mn109:17.4: consciousness at all—past, future, or present; internal or external; solid or subtle; inferior or superior; far or near, all consciousness—with right understanding: ‘This is not mine, I am not this, this is not my self.’
translation_text.mn109:17.5: Seeing this, a learned noble disciple grows disillusioned with form, feeling, perception, choices, and consciousness.
translation_text.mn109:18.1: Being disillusioned, desire fades away. When desire fades away they’re freed. When they’re freed, they know they’re freed.
translation_text.mn109:18.2: They understand: ‘Rebirth is ended, the spiritual journey has been completed, what had to be done has been done, there is nothing further for this place.’”
translation_text.mn109:18.3: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn109:18.4: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn109:18.5: And while this discourse was being spoken, the minds of sixty mendicants were freed from defilements by not grasping.
